data.title: Confusing error in ContentTypeReaderManager.LoadAssetReaders
data.body:
This error appears:

System.InvalidOperationException: Failed to get default constructor for ContentTypeReader. To work around, add a creation function to ContentTypeReaderManager.AddTypeCreator() with the following failed type string: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ListReader`1[[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix, MonoGame.Framework, Version=3.1.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]]

That implied to me I had to add something to ContentTypeReaderManager.AddTypeCreator()  when in reality you need to add a call to ContentTypeReaderManager.AddTypeCreator() 

A better error would be:

Failed to get default constructor for ContentTypeReader. To work around, add a creation function **by calling** ContentTypeReaderManager.AddTypeCreator() with the following failed type string: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ListReader`1[[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix, MonoGame.Framework, Version=3.1.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]]

I can make this change once someone confirms to me that I interpreted it right

data.title: Issue when IntermediateReader encounters an empty XML element
data.body:
When executing `IntermediateSerializer.Deserialize<T>()` against a simple XML asset, the XmlReader will not move off empty elements and continue reading content.

The issue appears to be in the `IntermediateReader::ReadRawObject<T>` method. When an empty element is found, the `ReadStartElement()` is not called on the reader and therefore the cursor doesn't move forward. Maybe if empty `XmlReader.Skip()` should be called after the line; `var result = typeSerializer.Deserialize(this, format, existingInstance);`?

You can reproduce this using the RolePlayingGame Starter Kit and in the `Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game` constructor try to Deserialize an XML content asset that has an empty element (LushVillage.xml). Here's what I used to reproduce, just change the paths accordingly:

```
XmlReader reader = XmlReader.Create(tempPath);
IntermediateSerializer.Deserialize<object>(reader, targetPath);
```

data.title: SoundEffect Errors on Application Close - Win 8.1 XAML Project
data.body:
I posted this on the CodePlex site but realized that this is a better place to put it. Here's the original topic (as well as a sample project that replicates the issue): https://monogame.codeplex.com/workitem/7897

Basically, I'm developing a Windows 8.1 game using XAML and MonoGame 3.2. I have a menu option that the player can click that exits the game using Application.Current.Exit(). If a SoundEffect is loaded through XNA's ContentManager, it causes an error similar to the following:

'MyGame.exe' (CLR v4.0.30319: Immersive Application Domain): Loaded 'C:\Users\me\Documents\Other Projects\Games\MyGame\MyGame\MyGame\bin\Windows8\Debug\AppX\SharpDX.XAudio2.DLL'. Cannot find or open the PDB file.
'MyGame.exe' (CLR v4.0.30319: Immersive Application Domain): Loaded 'C:\Users\me\Documents\Other Projects\Games\MyGame\MyGame\MyGame\bin\Windows8\Debug\AppX\SharpDX.MediaFoundation.DLL'. Cannot find or open the PDB file.

I have narrowed it down to SoundEffects, as when I don't load any the game closes just fine. I suspect there is some memory leak of some sort as this topic mentions: http://community.monogame.net/t/soundeffect-loaded-via-contentmanager-causing-memory-leak-after-resume/1174/2

I hope that this issue is resolved soon. Thank you very much!

data.title: PR3031 Enhance support for Windows 2008 server over remote desktop
data.body:
I will just repeat what I stated in Issue 3031:

I can run my monogame program on several windows 7 and XP, without any trouble.
When I try to run it on Windows 2008R2 Server accessed via remote desktop/spice (I have reproduced it on two virtual machines, one of them just installed and updated) it fails with exception:

Unhandled Exception: SharpDX.SharpDXException: HRESULT: [0x887A0004], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: Unknown
at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
at SharpDX.Direct3D11.Device.GetSupportedFeatureLevel()
at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.PlatformGetHighestSupportedGraphicsProfile(GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice) in c:\MinGW\msys\1.0\home\nologin\monogame\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\GraphicsDevice.DirectX.cs:line 1237
at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager..ctor(Game game) in c:\MinGW\msys\1.0\home\nologin\monogame\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\GraphicsDeviceManager.cs:line 67
at myPackage.myGame..ctor() in c:\ [...] \myGame.cs:line 123

According to http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb509553%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
that exception means:
DXGI_ERROR_UNSUPPORTED 0x887A0004 The requested functionality is not supported by the device or the driver.

Debugging monogame, I have also found that on the 2008 machine I can´t create a GrapchicsDevice with DriverType.Hardware (Reference and Warp drivers are ok), or with any FeatureLevel (not even 9_1).

I want to be able to run the program on windows 2008 server boxes, which needs the following corrections:
- Let the program run, although GetSupportedFeatureLevel() fails.
- Let the programmer choose the driver type (not only Reference driver, as it is supported now, but Warp too, which is faster)
- Check for supported FeatureLevels before requesting them, and if they are not supported, do not request them to the SharpDX.Direct3D11.Device constructor

---

By the way, the UseReferenceDevice that I replace with UseD3DDriverType, has not made its way to  stable yet.

data.title: BoundingSphere.CreateFromPoints returns incorrect results
VideoPlayer Improvements
data.body:
This PR has a couple of `VideoPlayer` improvements.

Most of our video players don't correctly report `MediaState.Stopped` when a video finishes playing.  So I added an internal `PlatformGetState` method that is called on each call to the `VideoPlayer.State` getter.  It was setup to be optional as I didn't have the time or ability to fix all the platform players to correctly support it.  I fixed the Windows desktop DX platform to support it and that is it.

I fixed `PlayPosition` for Windows desktop DX platform.

There is also a small fix to the unit test framework.  As part of this PR I was working on a unit test for `VideoPlayer`, but it just isn't ready enough to merge for now.

data.body: This fixes #3022. Parameter conversion is now done with `CultureInfo.InvariantCulture` so the decimal separators etc. should be the same regardless of user culture. data.title: Exclude sound effects from the Android MediaLibrary
data.body: The Android MediaStore includes all files that can be potentially played by a music player, including sound effects of other apps (like the facebook message pop effect). Therefore I think it's handy to exclude all audio files that are shorter than three seconds.

data.title: Fixed the unnecessary display rotation on Android
data.body:
If you launched a landscape game on Android if your device was in LandscapeRight, the game would rotate to LandscapeLeft at Initialize.

In order to avoid this, I had to get the orientation of the device to determine if it was LandscapeRight and start up as LandscapeRight instead of the fixed LandscapeLeft (I added the same code for PortraitDown).

However, Android is one hell of a complicated beast as we only get the orientation in degrees compared to the natural orientation of the device, which can be landscape in case of some tablets (like the Galaxy Tab 10.1). Thankfully all the code was already present in OrientationListener. AndroidCompatibility contained code to account for the swapped LandscapeLeft and LandscapeRight on Kindle, so I decided to move the code there from OrientationListener.

Now you can get the proper display orientation from AndroidCompatibility. It accounts for both the natural orientation and the Kindle landscape swap.

data.title: Fix for obscure bug on WP8
data.body:
There is a bug with the Obscure event.
The bug occurs sometimes when resume from the Lock screen and cause the
app to pause on a blank screen.
It never happens when the phone is attacked to the debugger so this
required some sort of on-screen logging to figure out.
(ver:8.10.14157.200, drv:3056.40000.1404.0003, Lumia Black) 

case #1
ApplicationIdleDetectionMode=Enabled (default)
App is suspended either by timeout or power button.

Obscured event triggered. IsLocked=true.
It's safe to ignore the Obscure event since the OS deactivates the app
anyway. IsActive is set to false by OnDeactivate.
When the user unlock the phone Unobscure event triggered but _SOMETIMES_
another Obscured event arrive after that, causing to app to remain in IsActive=false state.
That's why we need to ignore the event.

case #2
ApplicationIdleDetectionMode=Disabled
App is suspended either by timeout or power button.

Obscured event triggered. IsLocked=true.
We set IsActive=false on Obscure event as before.
When the user unlock the phone Unobscure event triggered and we set
IsActive=true.
Actually a second obscured event is triggered following by an
Unobscured, not an issue here.
In that mode the OS doesn't deactivate the app, allowing the app to run
under lock screen.
note: actually MonoGame doesn't allow run under lock screen
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2084.

case #3
ApplicationIdleDetectionMode=Enabled|Disabled
App is suspended by a phone call.

Obscured event triggered. IsLocked=false.
We set IsActive=false on Obscure event as before.
When the action that obscured the app ends, an Unobscure event is
triggered and we set IsActive=true. No bug here.
That is similar to case #2, the OS doesn't deactivate the app.
